title: Lichen Planus with Bilateral Conductive Hearing Loss
chief_complaint: My hearing was fine after my stapedectomies years ago, but it started getting worse about two years ago. It dropped quickly recently after I stopped my anti-inflammatory injections, and restarting them hasn't helped.

problem_summary.onset: Deterioration began approximately 2 years ago; recent acute worsening.
problem_summary.course: Fluctuating responsiveness to anti-inflammatory medication; currently stable but deteriorated.
problem_summary.laterality: Bilateral; Right ear is better than Left.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Diagnosed with lichen planus 8 years ago (affecting ears for 2 years).
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Monitor stability and discuss amplification options.

history.present_illness: Patient diagnosed with lichen planus 8 years ago; ear involvement began 2 years ago. Hearing deteriorated recently after stopping injected anti-inflammatory medication for 1 month. Resuming medication for 1 month showed no improvement.
history.otologic_history: History of otosclerosis. Stapedectomy Left ear (1993) and Right ear (2004). Hearing was normal post-surgeries until 2 years ago.
history.prior_management: Injected anti-inflammatory medication; previous hearing tests (unavailable).

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Right ear: Moderate rising to mild conductive loss (250-1000 Hz), becoming mixed at 2000-4000 Hz, sloping to profound. Left ear: Moderate conductive loss (250-4000 Hz) with a rise at 3000 Hz, sloping to profound. Significant air-bone gaps present bilaterally.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: SRT scores agree with PTA. Word recognition scores are excellent bilaterally at suprathreshold levels.

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.key_findings: Flat tympanograms bilaterally. Right ear has normal canal volume; Left ear has very small canal volume.

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with bilateral conductive hearing loss, with a mixed component in the high frequencies for the right ear. The hearing loss is moderate in the low-to-mid frequencies, sloping to severe/profound in the highs. Word recognition remains excellent despite the degree of loss. Tympanometry is flat bilaterally, consistent with the reported excessive tympanic membrane scarring and lichen planus involvement.
counseling_points: Your hearing test shows a conductive hearing loss, meaning sound is not being conducted efficiently through the middle ear, likely due to the scarring from lichen planus.
Despite the hearing loss, your ability to understand speech remains excellent when the volume is loud enough.
We will schedule a hearing aid evaluation to discuss amplification options that can help overcome this volume loss.
It is important to continue following up with your otologist to manage the lichen planus and monitor the health of your ear canals.
notes_for_actor: You have a complex history with your ears: successful stapedectomies years ago, but now lichen planus is causing new problems.
You are likely frustrated or concerned because the anti-inflammatory shots that worked before are no longer helping after you took a break from them.
You hear better out of your right ear than your left.
